Thank Riley County Attorney Wilkerson for being smart on crime and read our report on diversion.
  

Diversion makes Riley County Safer

Read our report and thank County Attorney Barry Wilkerson for acting in the best interest of Riley County.

Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

As you read this, nearly 10,000 Kansans – many with mental illness or substance abuse addictions – sit behind bars. Although the crime rate continues to fall to near record lows, our prison population is skyrocketing, pushing the system's capacity to its limits, wasting millions in taxpayer dollars, and causing irreversible damage to thousands of families impacted by the incarceration of a loved one.

We simply can't afford to continue at this rate. Something needs to change – and fast.

After months of exhaustive research, we released a report today identifying a smart tool county prosecutors can use to reduce the prison population, cut spending, and make our families and communities safer and stronger – diversion.

Diversion is a program in which non-violent, low-level offenders are able to complete alternative sentences, such as community service, restitution, or rehabilitation, instead of going to prison. This allows them to continue working and providing for their families, seek any necessary mental or behavioral health treatment, and remain a productive member of the community, which greatly reduces the likelihood that they will offend again.

Have you or a loved one been positively impacted by a diversion program? We'd like to hear your story.

Diversions can only be granted by a county prosecutor, not a jury or judge. And although prosecutors in counties all across the country consider diversion to be one of the best tools in their criminal justice toolbox, most prosecutors in Kansas refuse to give it even a fighting chance.

One of the few exceptions? Your very own county attorney, Barry Wilkerson! As Riley County attorney, he utilizes diversion in 13.9 percent of felony cases. This rate is much higher than the national average of 9 percent, and it's more than double the Kansas average of 5 percent!

By choosing to embrace diversion, County Attorney Wilkerson cuts down on thousands in government spending every year, prevents our county jails from becoming dangerously overcrowded, and most importantly, gives our friends, family and neighbors a second chance to become productive and law-abiding members of our community.

Prosecutors all across Kansas could learn a lot from County Attorney Wilkerson's smart approach to criminal justice. Make sure to send him a quick note to thank him for acting in the best interest of Riley County.

Sincerely,

Micah Kubic
Executive Director
ACLU of Kansas
